coredata.dc:title: Oxidation Characteristic and Machining Performance of Reaction-Sintered Silicon Carbide Ceramic in Anodically Oxidation-Assisted Polishing
coredata.prism:copyright: Copyright © 2016 The Authors. Published by ESG. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.prism:publisher: The Authors. Published by ESG. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:creator: Jiang, Guoliang
Shen, Xinmin
Tang, Jian
Zhang, Xiaonan
Zhang, Xiangpo
Yamamura, Kazuya
coredata.dc:description: A novel method for machining reaction-sintered silicon carbide (RS-SiC) ceramic using anodically oxidation-assisted polishing is proposed. Through anodic oxidation of RS-SiC, hardness of the oxidized sample can be reduced, and the soft oxide layer is easy to be machined with the assistance of abrasive polishing. In this way, fine surface quality and high material removal rate can be obtained in machining RS-SiC. The influences of process conditions on the oxide morphology, oxidation rate, and surface roughness have been qualitative investigated with scanning electron microscope (SEM) and quantitative analyzed with scanning white light interferometry (SWLI). The results show that anodic oxidation of RS-SiC by phosphoric acid (H3PO4) under the constant potential can obtain soft oxide and smooth morphology; abrasive polishing of oxide layer can obtain smooth surface with roughness rms 8.520nm. Relationship between oxidation depth and its influencing factors can be theoretical analyzed based on the oxidation mechanism, and the oxidation depth can be calculated by hydrofluoric acid (HF) etching of the oxidized sample. It can be concluded that the anodically oxidation-assisted polishing, which includes the anodic oxidation of RS-SiC by H3PO4 and abrasive polishing of oxide layer by ceria slurry, can be treated as a practical method to machine RS-SiC.
coredata.dcterms:subject: anodically oxidation-assisted polishing
reaction-sintered silicon carbide
phosphoric acid
oxidation characteristic
machining performance

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Oxidation Characteristic and Machining Performance of Reaction-Sintered Silicon Carbide Ceramic in Anodically Oxidation-Assisted Polishing Guoliang Jiang, 1 Xinmin Shen, 1 shenxmjfjlgdx2014@163.com Jian Tang, 1 Xiaonan Zhang, 1 Xiangpo Zhang, 1 Kazuya Yamamura, 2 yamamura@upst.eng.osaka-u.ac.jp 1 College of Field Engineering, PLA University of Science and Technology, Jiangsu 210007, China. College of Field Engineering PLA University of Science and Technology Jiangsu 210007 China College of Field Engineering, PLA University of Science and Technology, Jiangsu 210007, China. 2 Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka University, Osaka 565-0871, Japan. Graduate School of Engineering Osaka University Osaka 565-0871 Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka University, Osaka 565-0871, Japan. A novel method for machining reaction-sintered silicon carbide (RS-SiC) ceramic using anodically oxidation-assisted polishing is proposed. Through anodic oxidation of RS-SiC, hardness of the oxidized sample can be reduced, and the soft oxide layer is easy to be machined with the assistance of abrasive polishing. In this way, fine surface quality and high material removal rate can be obtained in machining RS-SiC. The influences of process conditions on the oxide morphology, oxidation rate, and surface roughness have been qualitative investigated with scanning electron microscope (SEM) and quantitative analyzed with scanning white light interferometry (SWLI). The results show that anodic oxidation of RS-SiC by phosphoric acid (H3 PO PO4 ) under the constant potential can obtain soft oxide and smooth morphology; abrasive polishing of oxide layer can obtain smooth surface with roughness rms 8.520nm. Relationship between oxidation depth and its influencing factors can be theoretical analyzed based on the oxidation mechanism, and the oxidation depth can be calculated by hydrofluoric acid (HF) etching of the oxidized sample. It can be concluded that the anodically oxidation-assisted polishing, which includes the anodic oxidation of RS-SiC by H ) under the constant potential can obtain soft oxide and smooth morphology; abrasive polishing of oxide layer can obtain smooth surface with roughness rms 8.520nm. Relationship between oxidation depth and its influencing factors can be theoretical analyzed based on the oxidation mechanism, and the oxidation depth can be calculated by hydrofluoric acid (HF) etching of the oxidized sample. It can be concluded that the anodically oxidation-assisted polishing, which includes the anodic oxidation of RS-SiC by H3 PO PO4 and abrasive polishing of oxide layer by ceria slurry, can be treated as a practical method to machine RS-SiC.Keywords anodically oxidation-assisted polishing reaction-sintered silicon carbide phosphoric acid oxidation characteristic machining performance References 1. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A novel method for machining reaction-sintered silicon carbide (RS-SiC) ceramic using anodically oxidation-assisted polishing is proposed. Through anodic oxidation of RS-SiC, hardness of the oxidized sample can be reduced, and the soft oxide layer is easy to be machined with the assistance of abrasive polishing. In this way, fine surface quality and high material removal rate can be obtained in machining RS-SiC. The influences of process conditions on the oxide morphology, oxidation rate, and surface roughness have been qualitative investigated with scanning electron microscope (SEM) and quantitative analyzed with scanning white light interferometry (SWLI). The results show that anodic oxidation of RS-SiC by phosphoric acid (H3PO4) under the constant potential can obtain soft oxide and smooth morphology; abrasive polishing of oxide layer can obtain smooth surface with roughness rms 8.520nm. Relationship between oxidation depth and its influencing factors can be theoretical analyzed based on the oxidation mechanism, and the oxidation depth can be calculated by hydrofluoric acid (HF) etching of the oxidized sample. It can be concluded that the anodically oxidation-assisted polishing, which includes the anodic oxidation of RS-SiC by H3PO4 and abrasive polishing of oxide layer by ceria slurry, can be treated as a practical method to machine RS-SiC.
